content: How can I help you today?
I've been having a really hard time sleeping lately. My mind just won't stop racing at night, and I can't seem to calm down.

That sounds really challenging—having your mind race at night can make it so hard to find rest. It must be frustrating to feel like sleep keeps slipping away. What do you think might be contributing to those racing thoughts?

It's mostly work. I've been really stressed about my job lately and worried about losing it. I think about how I'd manage to take care of my family if that happens, and I just can't seem to turn those thoughts off at night.

You're carrying a lot of weight on your shoulders, worrying about your job and your family. It's understandable those thoughts would feel overwhelming, especially at night when things are quieter and there's more space for them. How have you been managing all this stress during the day?

I’ve been trying to push through it during the day, but it’s really exhausting. At night, I find myself scrolling on my phone to distract myself, even though I know it’s probably not helping. I just don’t really know how to make it stop.

It sounds like you're doing your best to cope, but it hasn't been giving you the relief you need. Scrolling through your phone might feel like a quick distraction, but it hasn't helped calm your mind in the long run. It’s tough dealing with stress when it feels so constant. What kind of moments or activities, even small ones, help you feel a bit calmer, or offer some relief, if any?

It’s hard to think of anything that really helps. I guess spending time with my kids can sometimes distract me in a good way, but even then, it’s like the stress of work is always in the back of my mind. I feel like I’m not fully present with them because of it.

Spending time with your kids seems like it brings something positive for you, even if it’s hard to feel fully present because of everything else weighing on your mind. That shows how much you care about them, even amidst all your stress. When you do get those moments with your kids, is there anything about those times that feels especially meaningful or grounding to you?

I think it's just seeing them happy and being able to make them laugh. It reminds me of what I'm working so hard for, even though it doesn't take away the stress completely. I just wish I could be more in the moment with them without feeling so distracted by everything else.

It sounds like their happiness and laughter give you a sense of purpose, reminding you of why you push through the challenges. That’s really meaningful—even though it doesn’t erase the stress, it seems to give you moments of connection and joy. Wanting to be more present with them says a lot about the kind of parent you want to be. What do you think could help you feel just a little less distracted in those moments?

Honestly, I’m not really sure what would help. Maybe if I wasn’t so stressed about work, I could focus on them more. But right now, it’s hard to even think about how to fix that because it feels like the stress just doesn’t have an off switch.

It can feel overwhelming when stress seems constant and unrelenting, like it’s always in the background no matter what you do. Not knowing how to ease it is tough, especially when it also impacts how you connect with the people you care about most. If it felt manageable, would talking about what’s stressful about work help in untangling some of those concerns? Or do you feel you need a different approach?

I think talking about what's going on at work might help a little, but honestly, I'm not sure how much it'll really change anything. The main issue is that the company might start layoffs, and I feel like I'm not secure in my position. It makes me feel kind of powerless because it’s not something I can control, and that's part of what keeps me up at night.

Facing potential layoffs must feel so uncertain and out of your hands, especially when it impacts your sense of security. Feeling powerless can make it even harder to find calm when your mind won’t stop thinking about “what ifs.” It’s a tough place to be. What would it mean for you to feel just a little more in control amidst all this?

It would mean a lot. I guess if I could do something to feel like I’m being proactive, maybe it would help—like updating my resume or even looking for other opportunities just in case. But honestly, thinking about doing those things feels overwhelming on top of everything else.

Taking proactive steps like updating your resume or exploring other opportunities could give you a sense of control, but right now, it sounds like even thinking about that feels like adding to your stress. You're already carrying a heavy load. Breaking it into smaller, more manageable steps might make it feel less overwhelming. Is there a way to start small that feels doable for you, even if it's just one tiny action?

I'm open to trying something small. Maybe I could spend a few minutes this week just looking at job postings to see what's out there, without putting pressure on myself to actually apply yet. That might feel like a step in the right direction without being too much.

That sounds like a thoughtful step—just looking at job postings could help you get a feel for what’s out there without adding extra pressure to apply right away. It’s small, manageable, and still proactive, which might bring a little sense of control back to the situation. Is there anything else you’d like to explore or talk through before moving forward with this idea?
I think I’m okay for now. Thank you for listening and helping me think of a step I can handle. I’ll try to work on this a bit this week. I appreciate your help.
